abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Cotton Sub-sector
            Improvement Project (CSIP) for Uzbekistan was satisfactory.
            While overall performance of the World Bank and the borrower
            were both satisfactory, the Government implementation
            performance was unsatisfactory. Lack of experience in
            implementation of donor financed projects was the major
            reason behind delays during the first two years of the
            project. Some project activities got stuck into numerous
            disagreements between international and domestic norms,
            regulations on accounting, remuneration of consultants,
            taxation, civil construction permits, approvals and
            certification of works and imported goods. The lessons
            learned indicated that project design should have minimized
            the number of project executing agencies to maintain the
            integrity of financial control and direct responsibility of
            the project implementing agency over execution of the agreed
            program. Although, the planned sector reforms were not
            implemented, the CSIP achieved its operational goals.
